I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to $50,000,000 to Indorama Ventures Global Services Limited (IVGS) for the Indorama 
Ventures Regional Blue Loan Project in India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. The report 
also describes the proposed administration of a loan of up to $50,000,000 to be provided by the 
Leading Asia’s Private Infrastructure Fund (LEAP),1 and if the Board approves the proposed loan, 
I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the LEAP 
loan. 
 
2.  The loan will support Indorama Ventures group (IVG), a global integrated polyethylene 
terephthalate  (PET)  manufacturer,  for  their  expansion  of  PET  recycling  capacity  in  India, 
Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing will help 
promote a circular economy for recycled PET (rPET) with industry best practices in ADB’s 
developing  member  country  (DMC).  The  loan  will  be  ADB’s  first  internationally  verified 
nonsovereign blue loan, and ADB’s involvement will also ensure compliance with rigorous 
environmental and social safeguard standards. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT  
A.  Project Identification and Description 
3.  Plastics is a material of choice because of its availability, versatility, functionality, flexibility, 
and affordability. This has led to a surge in plastics production from 15 million tons (t) in 1964 to 
311 million t in 2014.2 Historically, plastics were mostly produced in Europe and the United States, 
but that has changed; as of 2015, half of the world’s plastics production has taken place in Asia.3 
Plastics production is correlated primarily with decreasing poverty, growing incomes, and rising 
consumption in fast-growing emerging markets.4 However, the cheapness and convenience of 
plastic also make it ubiquitous, resulting in one of earth’s greatest environmental challenges.5 
Indeed, plastics production is a primary driver of natural resource depletion, waste, environmental 
degradation, and climate change; additionally, it has adverse health effects. 
 
4.  In 2019, 95% of plastic packaging material value was lost after a short first use. More than 
40 years after the launch of the first universal recycling symbol, only 14% of plastic packaging is 
collected for recycling. This has led to an enormous marine plastic pollution problem that 
continues to grow. An estimated 150 million t of plastic is already in the ocean, and every year 8–
12 million t of plastic are added (footnote 2). Asia accounts for more than 80% of the total release 
of plastic into the ocean. The damage of plastic litter to marine ecosystems is estimated to cost 
at least $13 billion per year.6 Furthermore, plastic waste blocks rivers, streams, drains, and 
sewers, exacerbating flooding and creating breeding grounds for pests that transmit vector-borne 
diseases.7

5.  Marine plastic pollution is a complex multi-sectoral problem, largely resulting from (i) mass 
volumes of low-residual value, single-use, non-degradable plastics; and (ii) inefficient solid waste 
management and insufficient recycling systems. Plastic packaging is the most common item 
found during international coastal cleanups. Therefore, the traditional “take, make, dispose" 
approach  should  be  replaced  by  a  circular  economy  in  which  products  and  materials  are 
redesigned, recovered, and reused to divert plastic waste away from landfills and oceans and to 
reduce the environmental impact. Reduction of plastic waste, use of recyclable plastics, and 
improvement of collection and recycling systems should go hand in hand to enable the transition.  
 
6.  There have been increasing calls for action on marine plastic, including the Statement on 
Combating Marine Plastic Debris by the East Asian Summit Leaders in 2018. Many governments 
are taking steps towards the eliminations of problematic or unnecessary plastic packaging through 
regulatory or other policy actions (footnote 5). However, private sector responsibility is needed to 
tackle this issue throughout supply chains and lifecycles. Leading global food and beverage 
brands are making commitments to increase the use of recycled materials for their products.  
 
7.  PET is a type of plastic widely used in beverage bottles; global demand for PET reached 
25.8 million t per annum in 2018. PET products are durable, transparent, lightweight, non-reactive, 
cost-effective, and thermally stable, and PET is preferred to other types of plastic materials in 
terms of its environmental footprint since it can be recycled repeatedly.8 However, although PET 
has a higher recycling rate than any other type of plastic, there is room for improvement: globally, 
close to half of PET is not collected for recycling, and only 7% is recycled bottle-to-bottle (footnote 
2). In Asia, the collection rate of PET varies by country: it is more than 80% in Indonesia and 
Thailand, and only 40% in the Philippines. While PET has the greatest potential among plastic 
materials for the creation of a circular economy, PET’s collection rate needs to be increased, there 
needs to be better sorting, and more use of rPET in PET products will be required to reduce 
disposal of PET into landfills and oceans in ADB’s DMCs.9

B.  Project Design 
9.  ADB’s  assistance  will  be  provided  as  a  general  corporate  loan to  IVGS. IVGS  will 
downstream the loan proceeds to subproject companies for: (i) expansion and operation of PET 
recycling plants; and (ii) other sustainability initiatives, including energy efficiency, clean energy, 
and other sustainability projects; in India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. The rPET 
plants will produce rPET flakes and single-pellet solutions that will be processed into bottles and 
other PET products. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
 
10.  The entire ADB loan will be externally verified as a green loan based on the Green Loan 
Principles.12 Furthermore, the majority of the loan that will be utilized for IVG’s rPET facilities will 
be externally verified as a blue loan, following the Blue Natural Capital Financing Facility Blue 
Bond Guidelines,13 and will also be assessed against ADB’s Oceans Finance Framework once 
the framework is operational and if it demonstrates a significant and quantifiable contribution 
towards its objective.14 It will be ADB’s first internationally verified nonsovereign blue loan. 
 
C.  Borrower and Group 
11.  The borrower, IVGS, was established as IVG’s treasury entity at which its international 
borrowings are consolidated, and is a 99.9% owned subsidiary of Indorama Ventures Public 
Company Limited (IVL), which is the listed holding entity of IVG. IVG is a Thailand-based global 
petrochemical producer of PET, purified terephthalic acid, ethylene oxide, ethylene glycol, and 
polyester fibers. It is the world’s largest integrated PET producer, operating 119 manufacturing 
facilities in 33 countries across 5 continents. IVL is listed on the Stock Exchange of Thailand and 
had a total market capitalization of B115.7 billion ($3.7 billion) as of 2 October 2020.

D.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs  
15.  Impacts. The project is aligned with the following impacts: (i) Sustainable Development 
Goal (SDG) 14, target 14.1 (by 2025, prevent and significantly reduce marine pollution of all kinds, 
in particular from land-based activities, including marine debris and nutrient pollution) achieved; 
(ii) SDG 12, target 12.5 (by 2030, substantially reduce waste generation through prevention, 
reduction, recycling and reuse) achieved; and (iii) SDG 13 (take urgent action to combat climate 
change and its impacts) achieved.16 
 
16.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: quantity of plastic for recycling in 
India,  Indonesia,  the  Philippines,  and  Thailand  increased;  employment  generated;  and 
greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions avoided. CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED. 
  
17  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) PET recycling capacity of IVG is 
expanded in India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand; and (ii) blue and green loan status is 
achieved.  
  
E.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
18.  Consistency  with  ADB  strategy.  The  project  is  consistent  with  and  supports  two 
operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030: (i) operational priority 3 (tackling climate change, 
building  climate  and  disaster  resilience,  and  enhancing  environmental  sustainability);  and 
(ii) operational priority 4 (making cities more livable). It also supports Strategy 2030’s objectives 
of fostering regional cooperation and integration, and for ADB to expand private sector operations 
and to pursue development impact.17  
 
19.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project aligns 
with ADB’s Action Plan for Healthy Oceans and Sustainable Blue Economies,18 which calls for 
ADB to expand its investments and technical assistance to $5 billion during 2019–2024. One of 
the key objectives of the plan is to reduce land-based sources of marine pollution including 
plastics. ADB is also working on the Oceans Financing Initiative (consistent with the global 
Sustainable Blue Economy Finance Principles, to which ADB is in the process of becoming a 
signatory), to create opportunities for the private sector to invest in bankable projects that will help 
improve ocean health. Consistent with a “One ADB” approach, the project has benefited and will 
benefit from cross-departmental coordination on knowledge sharing.19 The project will help 
reduce GHG emissions by facilitating recycling of post-consumer PET, which is less energy 
intensive than producing virgin PET. Other sustainability initiatives including energy efficiency and 
clean energy will also contribute to net reduction of GHG emissions. Based on these, 90% of

B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
24.  Because of the COVID-19 pandemic, financial conditions have become tighter in Thailand 
and Thai companies are having more difficulty accessing long-term United States dollar financing. 
ADB’s  financing  package  provides  optimal  tenor  and  pricing  for  IVG  to  make  its  planned 
investment  in  recycling  facilities.  The  proposed  loans  will  finance  innovative,  high-impact 
technologies as well as process transformations that will improve recycling capacities and reduce 
GHG emissions. Additionally, ADB’s financing will enable IVG to confirm the loan as a blue loan 
and a green loan, allowing it to showcase its commitment to ocean-friendly investments and to 
position itself as the first mover for this new asset class in the regional loan market. This is a 
significant additionality since other financial institutions in Thailand do not have the relevant 
expertise or experience to do so.  
 
25.  ADB’s involvement and due diligence will ensure that the project is developed and 
operated to international best practice standards and performs to expectations over the project 
life.  ADB’s  participation  in  the  project  will  also  ensure  compliance  with  ADB’s  rigorous 
environmental and social safeguard standards.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
32.  ADB has categorized the project in compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement 
(2009)  as  follows:  environment  (category  B),  involuntary  resettlement  (category  C),  and 
indigenous peoples (category C). Safeguard Requirement 4 for general corporate finance is 
applicable.22 ADB’s loan proceeds will be earmarked to investments and other costs incurred in 
India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand.23 A qualified and experienced expert conducted 
a corporate audit of IVG’s environmental and social management system (ESMS), and its past 
and current performances against the principles and requirements of ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement.  The  audit  for  this  project  focused  on  the  facility  in  Nakhon  Pathom  province, 
Thailand.24 It is located in an industrial zone surrounded by agricultural land, which is not an 
environmentally sensitive area. 
 
33.  Environment. The corporate environmental policy requires IVG’s business operations to 
comply with legal requirements and to stay updated on applicable international codes, standards, 
and best practices. IVG requires subproject companies to achieve International Organization for 
Standardization  (ISO)  certification  for  quality  management  (ISO  9001),  environmental 
management (ISO 14001) and energy management (ISO 50001). On top of these, the Nakhon 
Pathom facility acquired certification on health and safety management (ISO 18001). The facility 
prepared an integrated management system manual for the management and mitigation of

Annual Report 2019, pp. 171–172 for programs’ overview). 
27 Under its corporate governance principles, IVL reports a functioning whistleblower mechanism and adequate 
coverage of gender-related matters in terms of sexual harassment and no discrimination. One of its principles being 
transparency, IVL is publishing on corporate matters, see for instance https://www.indoramaventures.com/en/our-
company/governance/whistleblower-reporting-channels.  
28 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

8 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Governments of the 
ADB member countries where the ADB loan proceeds will be utilized have no objection to the 
proposed assistance to IVGS. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and 
substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of 
Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$50,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to Indorama Ventures Global Services Limited 
for the Indorama Ventures Regional Blue Loan Project in India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and 
Thailand, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth 
in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa

metadata.Subject:
The project will support Indorama Ventures group (IVG) for their expansion of PET recycling capacity in India, Indonesia, the Philippines, and Thailand. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) financing will help promote a circular economy for recycled PET (rPET) with industry best practices in ADB’s developing member country (DMC).

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated October 2020 is provided for the ADB regional project 54333-001.
